citation.article-title: Characterization of halobenzoate-degrading, denitrifying Azoarcus and Thauera isolates and description of Thauera chlorobenzoica sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thauera chlorobenzoica sp. nov.

Thauera chlorobenzoica (chlor.o.ben.zo'i.ca. M.L. adj. chloro pertaining to chlorine, from Gr. adj. chloros pale green; M.L. adj. benzoicus pertaining to benzoic acid; M.L. fem. adj. chlorobenzoica indicating the ability to utilize chlorobenzoic acid)
Cells are short, fat rods with lengths of 1.2-2.7 μm and widths of 0.85-0.97 lm and with `degenerately peritrichous' flagellation.
Fig. 4 shows the cell morphology and flagellation of strain 4FB2.
All of the strains are oxidase- and catalase-positive.
The predominant fatty acids are 10:0 3-OH, 12:0, 16:1ω7c, 16:0 and 18:1ω7c, and a small amount of 17:0 cyclo fatty acid is also found.

They can grow under aerobic and denitrifying conditions with acetate, adipate, butyrate, glutamate, malate, ornithine, pyruvate, succinate, benzoate, phenylacetate, vanillate, 3-hydroxybenzoate and 4-hydroxybenzoate.
Under denitrifying conditions, 3-aminobenzoate, 2-fluorobenzoate and 4-fluorobenzoate are used.
In addition, strains 3CB-1T and 3BB1 can use 3-chlorobenzoate, 3-bromobenzoate and 3-methylbenzoate under denitrifying conditions.
The analysis of the 16S rRNA genes shows sequence similarity to T. aromatica K172T of more than 98%.
Strains 3CB-1T, 4FB1 and 4FB2 showed very similar ribotyping patterns, distinct from that of T. aromatica K172T.
The genomic DNA similarity measured using DNA±DNA hybridization is more than 70% within the species and in the range 45-65%with respect to T. aromatica strains K172T and T1.
Strain 3CB-1T was initially proposed as Thauera aromatica genomovar chlorobenzoica (Song et al., 2000a) because insufficient information was available to differentiate it as a new species.

However, additional isolates capable of halobenzoate degradation under denitrifying conditions were found to belong to this genomovar group (4FB1, 4FB2 and 3BB1) and showed clear genetic differences from the type strain of T. aromatica, K172T, and closely grouped strains.
Strains 3CB-1T, 4FB1, 4FB2 and 3BB1 are proposed as members of the new species Thauera chlorobenzoica sp. nov.
